<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">ACC2100</span> - Financial accounting<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACC2100">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-accounting.html">Department of Accounting</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Sunyoung Kim">Dr Sunyoung Kim</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Dharmendra Naidu">Dr Dharmendra Naidu</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Sunyoung Kim">Dr Sunyoung Kim</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Dharmendra Naidu">Dr Dharmendra Naidu</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACC2100&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACC2100&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACC2100">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACC1100.html">ACC1100</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACF2100.html">ACF2100</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACB2491.html">ACB2491</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACW2491.html">ACW2491</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit examines financial accounting issues associated with the operation of corporate structures. Topics include financial reporting requirements, financing company operations, business combinations, the nature of corporate groups, the preparation of consolidated financial statements and financial statement analysis.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain the regulation of companies and the content of company financial reports</li>
<li>critically examine current issues and disclosure requirements in financial reporting</li>
<li>apply accounting standards and the conceptual framework in the preparation and presentation of financial reports for consolidated entities</li>
<li>demonstrate accounting knowledge in areas such as company operations, taxation, property, plant and equipment, acquisitions, group accounting and financial statement analysis</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, research, problem solving, and written and oral communication skills to demonstrate the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by this unit.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2172</span> - Korean introductory 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2172">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-korean-studies.html">Korean Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andy Jackson">Associate Professor Andy Jackson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Andy Jackson">Associate Professor Andy Jackson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2172&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2172">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2171.html">ATS2171</a></span> or equivalent</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>Students enrolled in Arts courses are prohibited from taking this unit. In addition, students enrolled in this unit are prohibited from taking <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1172.html">ATS1172</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>If this is your language entry point, this unit requires a <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">language entry level test</a><span class="hbk-print-url">language entry level test (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Building on the foundation established in Korean Introductory 1, students will continue to develop their ability to communicate in routine social situations. They will also be introduced to various learning strategies that aim to help them develop a sense of control over their own learning, leading to a lifetime of learning.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completing this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Competently participate in simple Korean conversations about everyday life and familiar topics</li>
<li>Make requests, and express agreement and refusal</li>
<li>Read and write in defined contexts</li>
<li>Demonstrate  an increased understanding of Korean history, culture and society</li>
<li>Develop basic learning strategies that will prepare them for life-long learning</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BND4402</span> - Dietetic practice 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BND4402">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-nutrition-dietetics-and-food.html">Department of Nutrition, Dietetics and Food</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicole Kellow">Nicole Kellow</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Amanda Anderson">Amanda Anderson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BND4402&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BND4402&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BND4402">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>A student must have passed a minimum of 144 credit points of units deemed satisfactory and relevant in content and depth by the Nutrition and Dietetic Department Selection Officer in conjunction with the Unit Coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>BND students only.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Please note: The teaching dates for this unit vary from the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">standard teaching dates</a><span class="hbk-print-url">standard teaching dates (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span> for this teaching period.</p>
<p>Unit discontinuation and penalty dates for these units are different to other units taught in the same teaching period.</p>
<p>Please refer to the information available on the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">Faculty non standard teaching dates page</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Faculty non standard teaching dates page (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates</a>)</span> to avoid <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">academic and financial penalties</a><span class="hbk-print-url">academic and financial penalties (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is predominantly a placement based unit to support students' progression and entry level competencies in individual case management in a healthcare setting.</p>
<p>The key themes explored in this unit are Theme 3: Fundamentals of Health and Disease, Theme 1: Personal Development and Professional Practice and Theme 4: Food from Science to Systems as students' progress and integrate their dietetic practice skills and competencies working in the healthcare environment. There is  partial integration of content and application from Theme 2: Determinants and Influences on Population Health and Nutrition.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Apply knowledge of science, nutrition, diet and disease into assessment, education, and management of clinical cases in a healthcare environment</li>
<li>Integrate personal, social, clinical, cultural, dietary, economic, environmental, ethical, medical and physiological factors into clinical reasoning and decision making  in client centred case management in the healthcare environment</li>
<li>Achieve entry level competencies to support individual case management across a range of clients</li>
<li>Apply an evidence based approach to clinical case management</li>
<li>Integrate knowledge of food service systems and processes into case management</li>
<li>Exhibit excellent oral and written communication skills in all professional interactions with peers, colleagues, clients and other stakeholders in the healthcare and academic environments.</li>
<li>Work effectively as a member of the dietetic and broader healthcare team</li>
<li>Practice safely, effectively and professionally</li>
<li>Reflect on practice extending self-awareness, insight and cultural competency.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Each student will be allocated to a healthcare site of a placement partner of Monash University and the Department of Nutrition and Dietetics for a total of 36 placement days. University staff are involved in final placement assessment and signing off of entry level competency for the profession for the relevant units. </p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Major case oral presentation &amp; extension questions (15 mins) (15%)</li>
<li>Major case written report (3000 words) (45%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Critical incident related to patient management - guided reflection &amp; action plan (1500 words) (15%)</li>
<li>Ward round interview (30 mins) (10%)</li>
<li>Ward round nutrition care plan report (1,500 words) (15%)</li>
<li>Placement Portfolio (Hurdle) (Pass / Fail)</li>
<li>Practical competencies (Ungraded hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will spend the majority of time for this unit allocated to a healthcare setting (8 Weeks of either 4 or 5 days per week - a total of 36 days). Students will also be expected to attend tutorials and presentations in the academic setting (scheduled around placement commitments) with the remaining time allocated for private study. Students are expected to attend placement for the equivalent of full time hours (7 hours/day) during their scheduled placement weeks. It is also expected that students undertake private study outside of placement hours.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nutrition">Nutrition</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKF3461</span> - Marketing communication<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKF3461">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jiemiao Chen">Dr Jiemiao Chen</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jiemiao Chen">Dr Jiemiao Chen</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKF3461&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKF3461&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKF3461">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF2111.html">MKF2111</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKS2460.html">MKS2460</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKW2460.html">MKW2460</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKB2704.html">MKB2704</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKC3460.html">MKC3460</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The primary aim of this unit is to explore the use of marketing communication to build and sustain brands, based on knowledge of how communication works, the institutions which participate in the process and the practical business processes necessary to achieve and measure defined communication goals.  In particular, students will be able to understand the integrated nature of communication and develop a full appreciation of advertising, sales promotion, public relations, publicity and direct marketing in a digital and contemporary environment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>understand and describe communication theories, processes and models</li>
<li>construct an integrated marketing communication plan, including situation analysis, target audience analysis, communication objectives, communication strategy, creative strategy, media strategy, scheduling, budgeting, and monitoring and evaluation procedures</li>
<li>discuss, present, and critically evaluate practical issues in marketing communication using appropriate theories and terminologies.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">IDE2701</span> - Product interface design<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IDE2701">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robbie Napper">Dr Robbie Napper</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nyein Aung">Mr Nyein Aung</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IDE2701">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/DGN1001.html">DGN1001</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC2002.html">ARC2002</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/COL1001.html">COL1001</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces the topic of person/product user interface. The mechanical and electro-mechanical systems that determine the relationship between a user's action and its outcome. The unit focuses upon products, environments, and systems, defining their form as it relates to how they are used. The unit covers how these products will be situated socially and culturally.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Be able to analyse information and to interpret into a logical flow chart the information required for the operation of electronic and electro-mechanical products;</li>
<li>Develop sensitivity to understanding user interface issues such as conceptual models, affordance and mapping between interface and functions, as well as creating feedback to actions;</li>
<li>Develop and prepare a series of working graphic user interfaces from a given or developed database(s);</li>
<li>Understand and practice the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the industrial design studio.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Projects (100%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 hours studio contact and 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">TRC2201</span> - Mechanics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-TRC2201">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nabil Chowdhury">Dr Nabil Chowdhury</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Madhavan Shanmugavel">Dr Madhavan Shanmugavel</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=TRC2201&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-TRC2201">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Must have passed 42 credit points</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC2401.html">MEC2401</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Kinematics: position, velocity and acceleration; relative motion analysis and applications for particles and rigid bodies; Dynamics: translational and rotational motion of free and constrained forces, their origin and significance; equation of motion, principle of impulse and momentum, principles of work and energy; Analysis of planar motion. Fundamentals of mechanical vibrations. Strength of materials: stress and strain in 2D and 3D space; Hookes law; Shear force and bending moments, moments of area, deflection of beams; Equilibrium and compatibility equations; Stress and strain transformation; Mohr circle; Simple failure criteria; Elastic instability --- buckling.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe fundamental principles of kinematics of particles and rigid body motion in a plane.</li>
<li>Describe fundamental principles of kinetics of particles and rigid body motion in a plane.</li>
<li>Apply the principles of kinematics to solve questions of particles and rigid bodies.</li>
<li>Apply the principles of kinetics to solve questions of particles and rigid bodies moving in a plane.</li>
<li>Identify the key concepts of Mechanical of Materials (MOM).</li>
<li>Apply concepts of MOM to bending and torsion, and combined stresses.</li>
<li>Apply concepts of MOM to transformation of stresses, and failure theories.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Final Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours lectures, 3 hours of practice/laboratory classes and 6 hours of private study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKF2521</span> - Brand management<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKF2521">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mustabshira Rushdi">Dr Mustabshira Rushdi</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jasmina Ilicic">Dr Jasmina Ilicic</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jasmina Ilicic">Dr Jasmina Ilicic</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mustabshira Rushdi">Dr Mustabshira Rushdi</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKF2521&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKF2521&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKF2521">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF1120.html">MKF1120</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKB2706.html">MKB2706</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>A brand is much more than a logo, a symbol, a sign or device, or simply the result of clever advertising. It helps to communicate value and create and deliver that value. Branding is a promise of value for customers. It helps to attract and, if it is true and accurate, keep customers. It provides an extra element of understanding or meaning, for customers as they form opinions and make purchase decisions from a variety of competing offerings. There is strong industry demand for graduates with a thorough understanding of branding. While this unit is primarily for students undertaking a major in marketing it is offered to any student with a prerequisite of an introductory marketing unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>examine the brand and the various functions of brand management</li>
<li>describe the various components of a brand and how they interact</li>
<li>analyse branding techniques and apply them to a variety of different issues</li>
<li>generalise and hypothesise from branding theory into branding practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">MTH1010</span> - Functions and their applications<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MTH1010">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-mathematical-sciences.html">School of Mathematical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Simon Teague">Mr Simon Teague</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Simon Teague">Mr Simon Teague</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Daniel McInnes">Dr Daniel McInnes</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MTH1010&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MTH1010&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MTH1010">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>It is recommended that students will have successfully completed either VCE Mathematical Methods 1/2 or VCE Further Mathematics 3/4 or equivalent. Students without one of these may need to undertake additional private study beyond the normal workload requirements.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ENG1005.html">ENG1005</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ENG1090.html">ENG1090</a></span>, ENG1091, MTH1049, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1020.html">MTH1020</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1030.html">MTH1030</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1035.html">MTH1035</a></span> and MTH1040. Note that MTH1010 can only be completed prior to <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1020.html">MTH1020</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1030.html">MTH1030</a></span>/<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1035.html">MTH1035</a></span> or equivalent. Students who have achieved a study score of at least 25 in VCE Mathematical Methods units 3/4 (or equivalent) are not permitted to enrol in MTH1010.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Functions, domain and range, function representation; different types of functions including linear, exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric, polynomial and rational functions; function algebra; composition of functions; inverse of functions; transformations; modelling with functions; rates of change; introduction to differentiation and integration, including techniques and applications.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the properties of elementary functions by means of tables, graphs and mathematical expressions;</li>
<li>Manipulate functions using a range of methods from algebra and calculus;</li>
<li>Apply functions and appropriate mathematical tools to model simple physical systems;</li>
<li>Communicate mathematical arguments in written form.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>End of semester examination (3 hours): 60% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Hurdle requirement: To pass this unit a student must achieve at least 50% overall and at least 40% for both the end-of-semester examination and continuous assessment components.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Three 1-hour lectures and one 2-hour applied class per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC3448</span> - Engineering technologies<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC3448">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Scott Wordley">Dr Scott Wordley</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mohd Zulhilmi Paiz">Dr Mohd Zulhilmi Paiz</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Quota applies</p>
<p>Please note that this unit has quota places in Clayton and Malaysia campuses.
      
      
      </p><p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC3448&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC3448&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC3448">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Available only to Mechanical, Aerospace or Mechatronics students.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC2408.html">MEC2408</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces a range of fundamental technologies, processes and manufacturing methods used in the creation of engineering artefacts and explains their relative merits and limitations. 3D Computer-Aided Design and Manufacturing (CAD/CAM) tools are utilised to design and manufacture using rapid prototyping and additive techniques.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify engineering technologies, processes, materials and artefacts.</li>
<li>Select and apply appropriate protocols to ensure safety and environmental protection.</li>
<li>Use a range of fundamental technologies to construct engineering artefacts.</li>
<li>Design and construct an artefact, using computer-aided design (CAD), rapid prototyping and additive manufacturing.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of 4-6 hours of scheduled learning activities and 6-8 hours independent study per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. If independent study during mid-semester break, SWOTVAC and exam periods are included, the total workload can exceed the minimum expected workload.</p>
<p>NOTE: This unit is commonly taught in block mode (a single 5-hour workshop class each week) and these may be scheduled to finish as late as 10pm. Please contact your campus unit coordinator for more details.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT3077</span> - Software engineering: Architecture and design<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT3077">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Aldeida Aleti">Dr Aldeida Aleti</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT3077&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT3077">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2099.html">FIT2099</a></span> or (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2001.html">FIT2001</a></span> and (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2004.html">FIT2004</a></span> or FIT2024 or CSE2304)) or (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2001.html">FIT2001</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2081.html">FIT2081</a></span>)</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>CSE3308</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit builds on introductory units to analysis and design. It provides the professional software engineer with advanced knowledge and skills in high-level architectural design, its theoretical foundations, industrial best practice, and relevant application context. In the software life-cycle, software architecture sits between analysis/specification and design/implementation. The field of software architecture has come of age with a thriving research community and numerous high-level models, methods, tools and practices widely used in industry.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>model and design flexible software at the architectural level using various tools and techniques;</li>
<li>analyse and design software systems taking into consideration various quality attributes and requirements;</li>
<li>take requirements for simple systems and develop software architectures and designs at a high level;</li>
<li>use configuration management tools effectively;</li>
<li>apply a variety of design patterns, frameworks and architectures in designing software;</li>
<li>locate and use off-the-shelf components in the construction of software.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (3 hours): 40%; In-semester assessment: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:

<ul>
<li>Two hours of lectures</li>
<li>One 1-hour laboratory</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):

<ul>
<li>A minimum of 3 hours of personal study per one hour of lecture time in order to satisfy the reading, tute, prac and assignment expectations.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/advanced-computer-science">Advanced computer science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/software-development">Software development</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/software-engineering">Software engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MID2010</span> - Working with birthing women<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MID2010">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Bethany Carr">Ms Bethany Carr</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Bethany Carr">Ms Bethany Carr</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MID2010&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MID2010">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1114.html">NUR1114</a></span> or (BMA1912 and NUR1120) AND <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MID2000.html">MID2000</a></span> or (MID1002 and MID1003)</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MID2004, MID2105.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The focus of this 12 credit point unit is to develop midwifery knowledge and skills related to working with women throughout labour and birth.</p>
<p>This unit will enable students to develop skills and confidence in the clinical assessment of the woman and her baby. Students will revise the mechanisms of labour, and will describe, in-depth, the assessments undertaken by the midwife during labour.</p>
<p>Students will examine the theories of pain in relation to labour and childbirth. Students will be able to recognise variations from the normal birthing process, and describe the appropriate interventions for common at risk situations during childbirth.</p>
<p>The impact of current birthing options for women from all backgrounds will be explored. Both 'simulated' and 'real' opportunities to develop skills and knowledge will be provided, to enable students to provide effective care to birthing women.</p>
<p>The clinical practice component will provide students with opportunities to incorporate theoretical learning directly into midwifery practice.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain the comprehensive assessment and care of a woman, from all cultural backgrounds, and her baby, during the birth process;</li>
<li>Interpret the philosophical, physiological, psychosocial, spiritual, cultural and environmental factors influencing the birth process;</li>
<li>Discuss the midwife's scope of practice and collaboration with other members of the healthcare team, when working with women during childbirth;</li>
<li>Describe common variations from normal that may arise during pregnancy, labour, birth and the postnatal period and the midwife's role in managing these</li>
<li>Identify vulnerable populations within Australian society and examine  the impact of the current birth options for refugees, asylum seekers, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women;</li>
<li>Critique the implications of obstetric interventions and use of technology upon the woman and her family;</li>
<li>Critically reflect on the professional health care partnership role when working with vulnerable women and their families, during childbirth;</li>
<li>Recognise women's rights, values and cultural beliefs in creating an appropriate and culturally safe environment for women and their partners to birth; and</li>
<li>Demonstrate beginning level competency based upon the ANMC National Competency Standards for the Midwife.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Students are required to participate in 160 hours clinical placement. They are also required to continue with their Continuity of Care relationships with women (~20 hours per woman) x 4.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Assessment tasks Handbook entry description:</li>
<li>Written Assignment (2,500 words) (25%)</li>
<li>Written Exam (2 hours) (35%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Attendance at RANZCOG Fetal Surveillance Education Program (Pass / Fail) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Online quiz linked to Fetal Surveillance Education Program (10%)</li>
<li>Continuity of Care Case Reports (500 words x 2) (Pass / Fail) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Clinical Placement with Learning Tools and Skills Assessment (160 hours) (30%) (Pass / Fail) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Students must pass clinical placement to pass the unit</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Lectures: 2 hour x 8 weeks = 16 hours</p>
<p>Tutorials: 2 hours x 8 weeks = 16 hours</p>
<p>Self directed study: 40 hours</p>
<p>Clinical: 160 hours</p>
<p>Continuity of Care clinical hours: 80 hours</p>
<p>Total: 312 hours.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing-and-midwifery">Nursing and midwifery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3933</span> - The meaning of things: Writing cultural history<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3933">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-history.html">History</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julie Kalman">Dr Julie Kalman</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jamie Agland">Mr Jamie Agland</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS3933&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3933">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS2933</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Societies express themselves through art, literature, ritual, everyday objects and other cultural artefacts. One of the tasks of the historian is to understand this interplay of culture and society, and how it manifests in different historical periods or places.  In this unit we explore the ways in which historians of many different periods (from late antiquity to the present) write about culture, from 'great' art to the stuff of daily life. Students will be introduced to a broad range of cultural products and their meanings, and be required to undertake in-depth research into a topic, area and period of interest of their choice.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be expected to have:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critically engaged with different forms of cultural product, placing them in their historical and aesthetic contexts.</li>
<li>Understood the meaning of the term "Cultural History", including its historiographical implications.</li>
<li>Drawn on a number of theoretical frameworks in order to understand the history of culture.</li>
<li>Conducted research into a particular area of cultural history.

<p>Students successfully completing this unit at a Third Year level will have acquired, in addition:</p></li>
<li>independent research skills across a range of historical source areas.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">Bachelor of Global Studies</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Bachelor of Global Studies (<a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html</a>)</span></p>
<p><a href="../aos/history">History</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2640</span> - The ethics of global conflict<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2640">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robert Sparrow">Professor Robert Sparrow</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robert Sparrow">Professor Robert Sparrow</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2640&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2640&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2640&amp;tpCode=SSA-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester A</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2640">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Flexible)</li><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Flexible)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of first-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS3640, AZA2640, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AZA3640.html">AZA3640</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>The unit is offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/philosophy/flexible-learning/">Philosophy Flexible Learning program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Philosophy Flexible Learning program (<a href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/philosophy/flexible-learning/">http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/philosophy/flexible-learning/</a>)</span>.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">Summer Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Summer Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>When, if ever, is warfare justified? What about humanitarian intervention? What about violent revolution and terrorism? Why should civilians be protected in conflict? This unit will introduce students to theoretical approaches to the ethics of conflict that will allow them to answer these difficult questions. It will also serve to introduce students to basic ideas in moral and political philosophy. No background in philosophy is required: merely an interest in rational argument applied to global conflict.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Students successfully completing this unit will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>have a high level of understanding of the central ideas of just war theory</li>
<li>appreciate a wide variety of criticisms of just war theory</li>
<li>understand the connections between human rights and war</li>
<li>have developed the ability to apply theories of justice in conflict to actual cases from recent history</li>
<li>be able to develop and critically assess arguments about the justification of violence in the pursuit of political ends</li>
<li>have improved their ability to effectively communicate about complex issues in international affairs</li>
<li>have developed their ability to conduct independent research on topics of international justice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 70% + Exam: 30%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/holocaust-and-genocide-studies">Holocaust and genocide studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/human-rights">Human rights</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-relations">International relations</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-studies">International studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/philosophy">Philosophy</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKB2600</span> - Tourism marketing<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKB2600">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maureen Griffiths">Ms Maureen Griffiths</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maureen Griffiths">Ms Maureen Griffiths</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKB2600">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKB1700.html">MKB1700</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Tourism marketing provides students with a broad understanding of how key marketing concepts and theories can be applied to the tourism sector.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain the importance of marketing for the tourism sector</li>
<li>identify the marketing methods employed by the tourism sector</li>
<li>apply marketing concepts and theories to the tourism sector</li>
<li>analyse different marketing strategies within the tourism sector.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MPH5301</span> - Health systems and policy<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MPH5301">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-epidemiology-and-preventive-medicine.html">Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Micaela Drieberg">Micaela Drieberg</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Micaela Drieberg">Micaela Drieberg</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jane Banaszak-Holl">Professor Jane Banaszak-Holl</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MPH5301">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 4528, 4529, M6007, M6021</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The aim of this unit is to provide health service managers and public health practitioners with a comprehensive understanding of the major components of national health systems and how health policy is created to adapt and reform these systems.</p>
<p>Over 6 weekly modules students will explore relevant policy theories, stakeholders and policy actors and processes that address major health policy challenges. Each module includes an overview of the relevant concepts and resources, guided readings and online, instructor moderated, discussions of applied issues with student peers.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Outline the key structural components of national health systems.</li>
<li>Analyse the structure of their own health system.</li>
<li>Apply policy theories to contemporary health policy issues.</li>
<li>Analyse formal and informal sources of information guiding health system and policy development.</li>
<li>Analyse policy stakeholders and their policy interests.</li>
<li>Evaluate the role of the policy making process.</li>
<li>Critically appraise existing health policies.</li>
<li>Compose arguments on health systems and policy development.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Contribution to weekly online tasks (45%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Not less than 2 written assignments totaling 3,000 words (55%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Off-campus: 20 hours per week for 6 weeks.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/public-health">Public health</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT1043</span> - Introduction to data science<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT1043">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mahsa Salehi">Dr Mahsa Salehi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT1043&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT1043">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>VCE Mathematics Methods or Specialist Mathematics units 3 &amp; 4 with a study score of 25 or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1010.html">MTH1010</a></span>.</p>
<p>Note: For 2016 Further Mathematics with a study score of 35 will be accepted.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT5145.html">FIT5145</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit looks at processes and case studies to understand the many facets of working with data, and the significant effort in Data Science over and above the core task of Data Analysis. Working with data as part of a business model and the lifecycle in an organisation is considered, as well as business processes and case studies. Data and its handling is also introduced: characteristic kinds of data and its collection, data storage and basic kinds of data preparation, data cleaning and data stream processing. Curation and management are reviewed: archival and architectural practice, policy, legal and ethical issues. Styles of data analysis and outcomes of successful data exploration and analysis are reviewed. Standards, tools and resources are also reviewed.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain the role of data in different styles of business;</li>
<li>demonstrate the size and scope of data storage and data processing, and classify  the basic technologies in use;</li>
<li>identify tasks for data curation and management in an organisation;</li>
<li>classify participants in a data science project: such as statistician, archivist, analyst, and systems architect;</li>
<li>classify the kinds of data analysis and statistical methods available for a data science project;</li>
<li>locate suitable resources, software and tools for a data science project.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%; In-semester assessment: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for students:

<ul>
<li>Two hours lectures</li>
<li>Two hours laboratories</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements:

<ul>
<li>A minimum of 8 hours of personal study per week in order to satisfy the reading, tute, prac and assignment expectations.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/data-science">Data science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
