<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">GMA1010</span> - Foundations of medical practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">48 points, SCA Band 3, 1.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-GMA1010">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-rural-health.html">School of Rural Health</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Barton">Associate Professor Peter Barton</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Shane Bullock">Associate Professor Shane Bullock</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=GMA1010&amp;tpCode=FY-32&amp;tpYear=2019">Full year (extended)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-GMA1010">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-gippsland.html">Gippsland</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year (extended) 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in courses 4532 or M6018</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Please note: The teaching dates for this unit vary from the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">standard teaching dates</a><span class="hbk-print-url">standard teaching dates (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span> for this teaching period.</p>
<p>Unit discontinuation and penalty dates for these units are different to other units taught in the same teaching period.</p>
<p>Please refer to the information available on the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">Faculty non standard teaching dates page</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Faculty non standard teaching dates page (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates</a>)</span> to avoid <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">academic and financial penalties</a><span class="hbk-print-url">academic and financial penalties (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit reflects an introduction to the four themes of the Bachelor of Medical Science and Doctor of Medicine (MD) curriculum: Theme I (Personal and Professional Development), Theme II (Society, Population, Health and Illness), Theme III (Scientific Basis of Clinical Practice) and Theme IV (Clinical Skills).</p>
<p>Students begin to develop the knowledge, skills and attributes required by a medical student. Knowledge in the basic medical and behavioural sciences is developed within inter-disciplinary units related to clinical and other problems through problem based learning clinical case studies.</p>
<p>Clinical skills development introduces history-taking, physical examination and procedural skills through clinical skills tutorials and clinical placement activities.</p>
<p>Community partnership placements are also a part of the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify and develop strategies for their own health enhancement.</li>
<li>Examine the similarities and differences between ethical issues in personal and professional life.</li>
<li>Appreciate the legal framework within which medical practice operates and the legal basis of the doctor-patient relationship.</li>
<li>Differentiate ethical debates about the following: doctor-patient relation; health and illness; ideas of personhood and body.</li>
<li>Apply concepts of professional responsibility and public accountability with reference to the role of the courts and common law statutes and professional self-regulation.</li>
<li>Develop a perspective on issues of social equity, welfare, advocacy and justice, particularly as they relate to the practice of medicine.</li>
<li>Demonstrate that from their position of responsibility within the community they have knowledge and skills that can contribute to the well-being of those people who are disadvantaged.</li>
<li>Develop the concept of the 'whole person' and in particular, the social and economic context of health and illness.</li>
<li>Discuss different perspectives on health, illness and medical practice through application of the 'sociological imagination'.</li>
<li>Describe associations between health and illness and social influences such as culture, disability, place, rurality, social position, gender, ethnicity, ecology and access to healthcare.</li>
<li>Consider appropriate adaptations of healthcare practice to suit particular cultural and social circumstances.</li>
<li>Demonstrate basic skills in accessing and critiquing research materials from personal, print and electronic sources.</li>
<li>Discuss the basic concepts and methods of biostatistics in medical research and epidemiology.</li>
<li>Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of different epidemiological study designs.</li>
<li>Explain how rural diversity can impact on rural health, illness and health service delivery.</li>
<li>Articulate the relationship between data, information, evidence, knowledge and informed care.</li>
<li>Demonstrate in applied situations the following:
<ul>
<li>Enhanced information technology skills (searching and medical database identification skills, including computer presentation skills);</li>
<li>Application of critical skills to clinical and research questions;</li>
<li>Application of a range of knowledge based systems in clinical practice (bibliographic software, decision support systems).</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Discuss the theories and approaches to health promotion.</li>
<li>Participate in the basic health promotion process of program development, planning, implementation and evaluation.</li>
<li>Identify appropriate strategies for health promotion interventions including targeting high risk and population-based strategies.</li>
<li>Recognise the conceptual and practical implications of a Community Based Practice program.</li>
<li>Describe and discuss the health, illness and community services and facilities available in a rural, regional and outer urban location.</li>
<li>Describe normal cell and tissue structure and formation.</li>
<li>Identify the role of genes in health and disease.</li>
<li>Describe the immune system and immune responses in health and disease.</li>
<li>Discuss the pathophysiology and management of conditions caused by microbes.</li>
<li>Describe the pathophysiology of neoplasia.</li>
<li>Discuss the general principles, concepts and language of neuroscience that will provide a basis for understanding the neural control of body systems and neurology.</li>
<li>Outline the structure and functions of neurons, signalling mechanisms, drug actions and receptors, and the organisation, inter relationship and general function of all divisions of the nervous system.</li>
<li>Describe the function of peripheral sensory systems, the sensory pathways, the motor pathways and the importance of sensory feedback.</li>
<li>Explain the general and detailed organisation and function of the musculoskeletal system.</li>
<li>Discuss the theories associated with human psychology and describe the neurobiological basis of human behaviour.</li>
<li>Describe the structure and function of the healthy cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, endocrine, gastrointestinal and reproductive systems and the formation and function of blood.</li>
<li>Describe the general pharmacological principles and the mechanisms of action of therapeutic agents commonly prescribed to combat disorders of the musculoskeletal, nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, gastrointestinal, endocrine, reproductive systems.</li>
<li>Describe the mechanisms and effects of selected common pathologies affecting the musculoskeletal, nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, gastrointestinal, endocrine, reproductive system.</li>
<li>Describe the basic processes of reproduction and early development, comprehend infertility and strategies to manage reproduction and contraception.</li>
<li>Discuss how fetal conditions can determine adult disease, recognising how specific anomalies can be diagnosed prenatally and how some of them may be corrected or managed.</li>
<li>Describe the trajectory of human development and explain the normal growth pattern and the attendant nutritional requirements of individuals from birth to adulthood.</li>
<li>Demonstrate clear and appropriate communication skills and active learning with clarity, consideration and sensitivity to patients and other health professionals.</li>
<li>Describe the framework for taking a comprehensive medical history.</li>
<li>Demonstrate an awareness of basic ethical and legal issues when communicating with patients.</li>
<li>Describe the principles of clinical reasoning.</li>
<li>Describe the elements of a Mental State Examination  and perform a Mini Mental State examination.</li>
<li>Recognise the importance of context in medical history taking and the development of health conditions.</li>
<li>Apply a framework for taking a focused medical history in the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal, reproductive, haematological and endocrine systems.</li>
<li>Apply a framework for taking a sexual history using a patient centred, non-judgemental approach.</li>
<li>Perform a basic examination of the musculoskeletal, neurological, cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal, haematological and endocrine system using a systematic patient-centred approach.</li>
<li>Perform a systematic patient-centred examination of the breast recognising the importance of communication during intimate examinations.</li>
<li>Demonstrate a structured approach to describing the features of normal basic investigations including Chest X-ray, Abdominal X-ray and 12 lead electrocardiograph.</li>
<li>Describe the elements of the patient safety framework including hand hygiene, teamwork and communication.</li>
<li>Demonstrate a structured and empathic approach to dealing with emotion in the patient encounter in a simulated environment.</li>
<li>Perform a series of procedural skills in a simulated environment using patient centred communication.</li>
<li>Recognise the social and health needs of Indigenous communities in urban, rural and remote locations.</li>
<li>Discuss traditional Indigenous culture and the complexities of contemporary Indigenous societies in urban, rural and remote locations.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit requires students to undertake off-campus clinical placements. In the clinical setting students will have an opportunity to apply theory to practice under supervision. Attendance is mandatory for the clinical component of each unit.Students must be aware of the Faculty's Clinical Placement Guidelines.Students will not be permitted to attend any clinical placements unless they have current valid Working with Children and Police checks, and have a satisfactory immunisation status, all of which must be submitted to Faculty. Students participate in a clinical placement program within this unit of 8 days duration. They also participate in a community placement of 4 days, requiring current valid Working with Children and Police checks. </p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Attendance (80% mandatory class attendance) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Professionalism and engagement (7.5%)</li>
<li>Clinical skills competencies (5%)</li>
<li>Critical reflection on a learning experience (5%)</li>
<li>Mid-semester 1 examination (5%)</li>
<li>Community-Based Placement (CBP) program assignment (7.5%)</li>
<li>End-of-semester 1 written examination (3 hours) (10%)</li>
<li>Population health assignment (5%)</li>
<li>HHB / HLSD assignment (5%)</li>
<li>End-of-year summative OSCE (20%)*</li>
<li>End-of-semester 2 written examination (10%)*</li>
<li>Vertically Integrated Assessment (VIA) examination (20%)*</li>
</ul>
<p class="footnote">*A pass must also be achieved in the combination of last three assessment tasks (the End-of-Year summative OSCE, the end-ofsemester 2 exam and the VIA) (Hurdle)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On-campus: Class contact hours: 24 hours per week. Students would be expected to do a minimum of 24 hours private study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/medicine-and-surgery">Medicine and surgery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="https://www.monash.edu/study">Study</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/">2019 Handbooks</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item breadcrumbs__current"><a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units">Units</a></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMA5011</span> - Introduction to human bioscience for engineering<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMA5011">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Sharon Flecknoe">Dr Sharon Flecknoe</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Amanda Davies">Dr Amanda Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMA5011&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMA5011">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in course code: E6001</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1011.html">BMA1011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1901.html">BMA1901</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1012.html">BMA1012</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1902.html">BMA1902</a></span>, BMA1912</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will introduce students to the basic anatomy and physiology underlying human health and disease.</p>
<p>This unit will explore homeostasis and how the systems (integumentary, neuromuscular, endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory, lymphatic, digestive, urinary and reproductive) work together to maintain the body within narrow limits.</p>
<p>Students will engage in pre-class, in-class and post-class activities aimed to consolidate, explore and apply their understanding of the body systems studied</p>
<p>Students will be assessed by completing both individual and collaborative projects which identify ways that engineering can be used to solve problems within human health and disease.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the cellular and tissue organisation of the human body and explain the inter-relationship between structure and function</li>
<li>Identify the structural components of the musculoskeletal and integumentary systems and explain how they protect, support and move the body.</li>
<li>Compare the functions of the endocrine and nervous systems and describe the underlying physiology that allows communication between body tissues and the environment.</li>
<li>Explain the interdependence of the cardiovascular, lymphatic and respiratory systems and how they maintain homeostasis</li>
<li>Identify the structures of the digestive and urinary systems and explain their roles in digestion and fluid balance.</li>
<li>Compare the structure and function of the male and female reproductive systems and explain how they work to produce offspring</li>
<li>Apply knowledge of  basic bioscience to real-world health problems that may be solved by engineering</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Instant feedback assessment of prior learning (10%)</li>
<li>iSAP assignment (30%)</li>
<li>Group project (35%)</li>
<li>End of semester test (25%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>2 - 4 hours face-to-face contact hours per week (lectorials and workshops)</p>
<p>2 - 4 hours (approx.) of guided self-paced online pre-class activities</p>
<p>2 - 4 hours private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BFM5959</span> - Accounting and finance for international managers<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BFM5959">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-banking-and-finance.html">Department of Banking and Finance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ravichandran Subramaniam">Dr Ravichandran Subramaniam</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFM5959&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFM5959&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BFM5959">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Evening)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in course B6007.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFS5959.html">BFS5959</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFZ5959.html">BFZ5959</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides an introduction to terminology, concepts and techniques used in accounting and finance. Important areas to be discussed include understanding financial statements, basic analysis of financial statements, working capital management, the framework of capital budgeting, and time value of money. International issues in accounting will also be examined. The emphasis will be on decision making and value creation in a global environment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop an understanding of the nature and roles of accounting and finance in managing in a global environment</li>
<li>explore the process of value management in a global world</li>
<li>develop competencies and computational skills required to prepare and evaluate the strategies and tactics associated with value creation</li>
<li>develop an appreciation for the relevance of theory and its linkage with practice</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with principles of accounting and finance and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered in the unit.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 40% + Examination: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2110</span> - Slavery: A history<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2110">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-history.html">History</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Timothy Verhoeven">Dr Timothy Verhoeven</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Timothy Verhoeven">Dr Timothy Verhoeven</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2110&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2110">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of first-year Arts units.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Slavery has existed since ancient times and has been used in societies as diverse as Ancient Rome and modern India, medieval Europe and nineteenth-century America. It still exists, in various forms, today. The unit investigates the meaning and experience of enslavement in a range of historical contexts. How and why have people been enslaved and what did it mean to live in slavery? How might slaves understand and achieve their freedom? Why have so many societies used slave labour? In recent times, attitudes to enslavement have changed, leading to campaigns against slavery in modern times: why did this happen, and to what extent have these campaigns been successful?</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>have acquired appropriate bibliographical skills, including critical use and analysis of digital and online material</li>
<li>Be able to identify the historical problems and issues addressed in secondary sources, both written and online</li>
<li>Demonstrate a capacity for independent thought and reflection and for constructing evidence-based arguments in their writing and verbal participation</li>
<li>Demonstrate oral and written skills in using a variety of primary and secondary sources</li>
<li>Show that they can use visual sources for historical analysis</li>
<li>Have gained a broad understanding of the long history of slavery</li>
<li>Be aware of several different approaches to the interpretation of history</li>
<li>Have reflected on the different ways in which experience is historically constructed</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/history">History</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_law"><span class="unitcode">LAW4306</span> - Sentencing and sanctions<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-LAW4306">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_law">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-law.html">Law</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
    
      
        
        Summer B:
        <a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Arie Freiberg">Emeritus Professor Arie Freiberg</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=LAW4306&amp;tpCode=SSB-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester B</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-LAW4306">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Summer semester B 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB (Hons) course in 2015 or later:</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1111.html">LAW1111</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1114.html">LAW1114</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1112.html">LAW1112</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1113.html">LAW1113</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2101.html">LAW2101</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2102.html">LAW2102</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2112.html">LAW2112</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2111.html">LAW2111</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW4332.html">LAW4332</a></span></p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB course prior to 2015: LAW1100 OR LAW1101; LAW1102 or LAW1104; LAW3300 or LAW3301 and LAW3302</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This course deals with the legal framework within which offenders are sentenced locally and nationally. It will examine sentencing principles applicable under state and federal law in Victoria. The course will examine the sources of sentencing law; the distribution of sentencing authority between the legislature, judiciary and executive arms of government; the control of sentencing discretion; the role of counsel in the sentencing hearing; plea negotiation, and the opportunity for public and victim input. Main sentencing measures and procedures currently utilised will be explored. The problems of sentencing special offender groups and special sanctions such as confiscation of the proceeds of crime will also be examined if time allows. The unit may cover:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Introduction to the legislative, judicial and executive framework of sentencing authority in a federal system of government.</li>
<li>Content of the Sentencing Act 1991 (Vic) &amp; Crimes Act 1914 (Cth), Part 1B</li>
<li>Courts exercising sentencing powers.</li>
<li>The sentencing hearing - role of the trial judge; roles of prosecution and defence counsel; plea negotiation; victim impact statements; the role of the Sentencing Advisory Council; role of the media and the community.</li>
<li>Evidentiary rules and burden of proof at the sentencing hearing.</li>
<li>Plea making: mitigation and aggravation.</li>
<li>Philosophical underpinnings: retribution deterrence, community protection, denunciation, rehabilitation, mitigation and mercy.</li>
<li>Sentencing principles: nature of the crime; nature of the offender; response to the charges</li>
<li>Main sanctions: fines; restitution and compensation; confiscation and disqualification; unsupervised release; community correction orders; custodial orders; parole.</li>
<li>Special offender groups e.g. juveniles; sex offenders.</li>
<li>Controlling sentencing discretion - the various models.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completing this unit, students should:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>possess an overview of the legal framework within which offenders against federal and state law in Victoria are sentenced or subjected to other measures such as civil action for confiscation of proceeds of crime under state or federal law, or administrative sanctions such as infringement notices, or other post sentence sanctions such as detention and supervision orders, or orders made under the Sex Offenders Registration Act 2004 (Vic);</li>
<li>appreciate the role that problem-oriented or solution-focused courts have in relation to the sentencing of drug dependent or mentally disordered persons, family violence offenders and Koorie offenders;</li>
<li>understand some of the empirical and criminological dimensions of sentencing;</li>
<li>have obtained an overview of different philosophical underpinnings of the sentencing systems.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>30% written assignment of 1500 words AND an individual research paper of 3500 words 70%.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<nav class="breadcrumbs mobile-hidden" id="breadcrumbs">
<p class="visuallyhidden" id="breadcrumb__label">You are here:</p>
<ul aria-labelledby="breadcrumb__label" class="breadcrumbs__list">
<li class="breadcrumbs__item home">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="https://www.monash.edu/">Home</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="https://www.monash.edu/study">Study</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/">2019 Handbooks</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item breadcrumbs__current"><a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units">Units</a></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">VCO2204</span> - Illustration as design<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-VCO2204">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ned Culic">Mr Ned Culic</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tracie Grimwood">Ms Tracie Grimwood</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=VCO2204&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-VCO2204">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span> &amp; must be enrolled in MADA course or by permission</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>VCO3205</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will emphasise the principle role illustration plays in the practice of graphic design. While continuing to develop individual illustration skills, students will be expected to realise their images in their intended contexts, such as packaging design, shopping bags, book covers, posters, advertisements, or other traditional graphic design formats. While being exposed to traditional image making processes students will also be encouraged to explore more experimental methods. A mix of hand generated imagery and digital methods will be encouraged.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Use a variety of illustration techniques: traditional, electronic and experimental;</li>
<li>Explore the potential for illustration to answer a range of graphic design problems;</li>
<li>Apply the principles of composition to the practice of illustration, and its surrounding design elements;</li>
<li>Understand the historical development of illustration in the practice of graphic design and comprehend its ability to become the principle visual focus of a major design project;</li>
<li>Successfully unite illustration with typography and other essential design elements;</li>
<li>Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours plus 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">IDE2810</span> - Furniture 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IDE2810">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robbie Napper">Dr Robbie Napper</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nicholas Found">Mr Nicholas Found</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IDE2810&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IDE2810&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IDE2810">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC2002.html">ARC2002</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/DGN2003.html">DGN2003</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IDE2113.html">IDE2113</a></span> or IAR2113 or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IAR2115.html">IAR2115</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CDS2001.html">CDS2001</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/IDN2001.html">IDN2001</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SDN2001.html">SDN2001</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides an overview of furniture design practice in Industrial Design. It outlines specific issues of the design process with particular reference to form, materials and structure. Methods of design communication and presentation are explored and applied.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand the diversity of materials and processes for making furniture;</li>
<li>Have increased sophistication in ergonomic analysis;</li>
<li>Understand constructional requirements and techniques;</li>
<li>Understand the development of furniture design concepts;</li>
<li>Undertake simple three-dimensional projects with regard to functional, technical, structural and aesthetic design criteria;</li>
<li>Understand and practice the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the industrial design studio.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours plus 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR2227</span> - Primary health care and health promotion in nursing and midwifery contexts<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR2227">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kerry Hampton">Dr Kerry Hampton</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kerry Hampton">Dr Kerry Hampton</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kaori Shimoinaba">Dr Kaori Shimoinaba</a>
        
        (Peninsula)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR2227&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR2227">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1013.html">NUR1013</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1111.html">NUR1111</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1113.html">NUR1113</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in M2006 &amp; M3007</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit builds on the content covered in <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1110.html">NUR1110</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1111.html">NUR1111</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1113.html">NUR1113</a></span> related to society, population health and illness, the Australian healthcare system and personal and professional development. Students are introduced to the key philosophies and frameworks that guide the delivery of sustainable primary healthcare in Australian and global context.</p>
<p>Students will examine the health of populations, families and individuals as they relate to health priorities, disease prevention, and continuity of care.</p>
<p>Primary health care in Australia and internationally is aimed at reducing the incidence of preventable diseases, and includes an emphasis on nursing and midwifery interventions which promote well-being and self-reliance for client groups.</p>
<p>Case based learning will enable students to critique evidence related to the provision of primary health nursing and midwifery care.</p>
<p>The concept of primary health care and health promotion, underpinned by a philosophy of 'health for all' will be explored involving: partnership development, community participation, health equity, social justice, capacity building and advocacy necessary to plan, implement and evaluate health promotion practice across all sectors. Simulated practice activities will feature skill development in working as part of an integrated interdisciplinary team, including carers, family, and unregulated workers.</p>
<p>This unit explores the role of nurses and midwives in primary health care and health promotion and enables students to understand and act on the factors that cause poor health, and those that create and sustain good health.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse the key philosophies and frameworks of primary healthcare and health promotion applied in the context of Nursing and Midwifery.</li>
<li>Conceptualise the biomedical, behavioural, and socio-environmental approaches to health and health care, and apply these to planning and evaluating sustainable health promotion programs</li>
<li>Analyse the concepts of partnership development, community participation, health equity, social justice and capacity building when working with vulnerable populations in primary health care including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples</li>
<li>Recognise the role of health literacy and behaviour change in improving health outcomes for various populations including, regional, rural and remote settings</li>
<li>Analyse health policy and the ethics of primary health care in relation to the role of the nurse and midwife</li>
<li>Explore contemporary challenges and future trends in primary healthcare including refugee health, planetary health and the changing healthcare sector</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Group presentation and health promotion program plan (20 minutes and 1,500 words) (35%)</li>
<li>iSAP written task (1,850 words) (35%)</li>
<li>Essay (1,500 words) (30%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On Campus</p>
<p>1 hour interactive lecture per week x 6 weeks</p>
<p>2 hour workshop per week (active learning) x 6 weeks</p>
<p>Teacher Directed Activities</p>
<p>4 hours Guided Learning Activities (E-Books: 'Prepare, Explore, Apply') per week x 6 weeks</p>
<p>10 hours SDL per week x 12 weeks</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing">Nursing</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing-and-midwifery">Nursing and midwifery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC3416</span> - Engineering design 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC3416">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jing Fu">Dr Jing Fu</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Lim Jen Nee">Ms Lim Jen Nee</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC3416&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC3416">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC2402.html">MEC2402</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>None</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MEC2406</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>In this integrative level 3 unit students of mechanical engineering programs are introduced to the design of machine elements covering bearings, shafts, welds, fasteners, gears etc. This leads to an examination of techniques for improving engineering designs based on economic and functional considerations. Geometric and economic tolerancing is further explored. The use of solid modelling software to simulate the behaviour of mechanical devices and produce engineering drawings is introduced. The integration of design skills and related engineering studies is covered through a group exercise to design a mechanical device.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Integrate first and second year studies into whole design tasks involving a combination of individual and group work</li>
<li>Design moderately complex mechanical devices with mechanical elements, such as bearing, shafts, fasteners etc</li>
<li>Evaluate mechanical designs by using conventional mathematical techniques including load analysis and stress analysis.</li>
<li>Geometrically and kinematically construct virtual devices in solid modeling software</li>
<li>Learn to communicate effectively in written, oral and graphical forms through the group project</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Laboratories, Tutorials and Group Projects: 70 %</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 30 %</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours lectures, 2 hours practical classes and 7 hours of private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/mechanical-engineering">Mechanical Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item breadcrumbs__current"><a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units">Units</a></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMS1021</span> - Cells, tissues and organisms<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMS1021">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julia Choate">Dr Julia Choate</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chantal Hoppe">Dr Chantal Hoppe</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS1021&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMS1021">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (including double degree programs)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (Scholar Program)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science Advanced with Honours</li>
</ul>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1011.html">BIO1011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1022.html">BIO1022</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces the student to the fundamental units of life (the cells) and explores how cells come together to form primary tissues which subsequently combine to form the organ systems and ultimately the living organism.</p>
<p>Cellular structure and metabolism is studied including the chemical constituents of living cells and the biological reactions that take place in them. Basic developmental biology concepts associated with the patterning of the body plan and embryological origins of cells and tissues are introduced.</p>
<p>The unit also introduces students to the microbial world and explores the structure and function of the immune system and how the body develops an immune response.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the properties and function of cells and explain how the primary tissue types combine to form a complete organism;</li>
<li>Describe the effects of cellular mechanisms and environmental impacts on human development, and identify how they are applied in health and biotechnology;</li>
<li>Describe the ways in which organisms regulate their internal systems and environment;</li>
<li>Explain the principles behind the development of an immune response and the role of microorganisms in health and disease;</li>
<li>Critically evaluate the relevant literature in the synthesis of a written assessment on an area contemporary biomedical research.</li>
<li>Perform laboratory techniques integral to the study of biomedical sciences and analyse and interpret results in consultation with research literature.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written assessment (1,000 words) (15%)</li>
<li>Practical class reports (25%)</li>
<li>Mid-semester summative test (1 hour) (10%)</li>
<li>Final exam (2 hours) (50%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 lectures and a 3-hour practical or equivalent per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RAD2061</span> - Radiologic biology 3<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RAD2061">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Imelda Williams">Mrs Imelda Williams</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wendy MacLeod">Dr Wendy MacLeod</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RAD2061&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RAD2061">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Level 1 of BRadMedImag course.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD2051.html">RAD2051</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Please note: The teaching dates for this unit vary from the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">standard teaching dates</a><span class="hbk-print-url">standard teaching dates (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span> for this teaching period.</p>
<p>Unit discontinuation and penalty dates for these units are different to other units taught in the same teaching period.</p>
<p>Please refer to the information available on the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">Faculty non standard teaching dates page</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Faculty non standard teaching dates page (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates">https://www.monash.edu/medicine/study/student-services/non-standard-dates</a>)</span> to avoid <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">academic and financial penalties</a><span class="hbk-print-url">academic and financial penalties (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units">https://www.monash.edu/enrolments/change/add-or-discontinue-units</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides a basic understanding of the human body, its structure and the function of its organs in health and disease. The unit covers the cardiovascular system, respiratory system, renal system, haematopoietic system, gastrointestinal system, endocrine system and reproduction. The unit incorporates the anatomy, physiology, pathology and radiographic imaging techniques related to each system. An introduction to the pharmacological principles underlying drug action, drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion and the adverse reactions to contrast media complements the body systems.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the anatomy &amp; physiology of the haematological, respiratory, cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, reproductive, urinary  and gastrointestinal systems and the significance for medical imaging examinations</li>
<li>Discuss pathological processes associated with haematological, respiratory, cardiovascular,  respiratory, endocrine, reproductive, urinary  and gastrointestinal systems</li>
<li>Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts of pharmacology, pharmacokinetics and toxicology;</li>
<li>Explain the general principles, risks, classification, structure and properties of radiographic contrast media;</li>
<li>Describe the prevention, treatment and support for contrast media reactions; and the characteristics of other drugs used in the clinical setting, general and local anaesthesia and their implications for patient care during diagnostic imaging examinations;</li>
<li>Identify and describe the radiographic representation of the organs comprising cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, endocrine, reproductive systems;</li>
<li>Identify and describe the radiographic appearances of pathologies affecting the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, endocrine and reproductive systems;</li>
<li>Identify and describe the angiographic representation of normal anatomy</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written exam (3 hours) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>2 x Mid-semester tests (1 hour each) (25%)</li>
<li>Group assessment (15%)</li>
<li>Image recognition exam (1 hour) (20%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hr directed and 12 hr self-directed study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/radiography-and-medical-imaging">Radiography and medical imaging</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/radiation-sciences">Radiation sciences</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">AZA3259</span> - Geographical information systems (GIS): Planning and decision making<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AZA3259">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-south-africa-school-of-social-science.html">South Africa School of Social Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Agnes Babugura">Dr Agnes Babugura</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Shelter Khuzhazha">Ms Shelter Khuzhazha</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AZA3259">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>AZA2259, ATS2259, ATS3259</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit introduces GIS (Geographical Information Systems) and discusses basic principles, techniques and applications of GIS in the field of geography and environmental science. It examines and reviews specific applications  where GIS is a useful tool. Subjects covered include basics of GIS, spatial data sources, spatial data quality, spatial data analysis and decision support systems. It also includes the basic principles of remote sensing and the use of satellite imagery. Cases studies and hands-on practices allow students to gain experience in the use of GIS.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the end of the unit students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate the utility of digital spatial data handling for mapping and analysis from digital data, referring to themes in environmental science;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a clear understanding of the key concepts concerning the application of GIS to environmental problems</li>
<li>Explain how value can be added to the data in any information management system with geocodes, by implementing digital spatial data analysis;</li>
<li>Be able to assess the nature of digital spatial data, offer tests for validation and descriptions of the relative value of data sets compared with (raw) data supplied by custodians;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a high level of skills in the use of GIS software (Quantum GIS, Ilwis, ArcGIS) to solve environmental problems;</li>
<li>Develop your own environmental applications of GIS ;</li>
<li>Explain how digital spatial data handling is different from other digital data handling challenges, and how the theory on which it is based is central to spatial data handling for environmental science.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/geography-and-environmental-science---south-africa">Geography and environmental science - South Africa</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/criminology-and-criminal-justice---south-africa">Criminology and criminal justice - South Africa</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS1248</span> - Introducing archaeology 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS1248">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-centre-for-ancient-cultures.html">Centre for Ancient Cultures</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hilary Gopnik">Dr Hilary Gopnik</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hilary Gopnik">Dr Hilary Gopnik</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS1248&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS1248">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit examines how archaeological and historical evidence can be used to study territorial and cultural expansion in the past. We focus on the development of the first empires in the Mediterranean including Assyria, Babylon, Persia, Athens, Macedonia of Alexander the Great, and Rome as well as the original spread of settlements in Australia and the Pacific. We explore how archaeological remains and historical texts can be used to study the movement of people and ideas and to identify the tactics states use to expand, strengthen, and celebrate their power, including military conquest, colonisation, trade, art, and literature. We examine the military ideology of the Assyrians, the internationalism of the Persians, the culture of classical Athens that built the Parthenon, the sweeping conquests of Alexander the Great, the hybrid culture of Kleopatra's Egypt, and the economic-military power of Rome under Caesar and Augustus. Hands-on tutorials explore the archaeological and historical methods used to reconstruct complex ancient societies.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>recognize the range of archaeological material available for use in the reconstruction of complex societies and empires;</li>
<li>understand the advantages and limitations of the different methods employed in reconstructing past societies and cultural contacts;</li>
<li>know the major cultures and historical periods of the Mediterranean from 1000 BCE to the fall of Rome, as well as key points in the settlement of Australia and the South Pacific;</li>
<li>identify the different tactics used by empires to incorporate, influence, and appropriate the territory and culture of surrounding regions;</li>
<li>analyse the structure and significance of the cultural exchange that operated between regions;</li>
<li>critically appraise arguments about past communities through the use of archaeological and historical evidence.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 70% + Exam: 30%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/archaeology-and-ancient-history">Archaeology and ancient history</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<nav class="breadcrumbs mobile-hidden" id="breadcrumbs">
