<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT4441</span> - Honours thesis part 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT4441">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pari Delir Haghighi">Dr Pari Delir Haghighi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT4441&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT4441&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT4441">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to an FIT Honours program.</p>
<p>Students in C3001 must have competed 144 credit points towards their degree including <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2083.html">FIT2083</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>For all students OTHER than C3001: <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4005.html">FIT4005</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>CPE4000, CSE4000, IMS4000, FIT4126, FIT4186, FIT4246, FIT4606</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is a research unit and a core unit for all Faculty of Information Technology Honours degrees. Due to the nature of IT, a wide range of Honours project types can be offered to students. Some project components are of a practical nature and may involve some software development and/or experimentation, while other components are of a more theoretical nature.</p>
<p>This unit forms part of the sequence of units comprising the Honours thesis in the Faculty of Information Technology.</p>
<p>Two exit points exist for the Honours thesis, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4444.html">FIT4444</a></span> (24 pts) and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4448.html">FIT4448</a></span> (18 pts). The 24 credit point exit point is applicable to:</p>
<p>Bachelor of Business Information Systems (Honours), Bachelor of Computer Science (Honours), Honours degree of Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences, Bachelor of Information Technology and Systems (Honours) and Bachelor of Informatics and Computation Advanced (Honours).</p>
<p>The 18 credit point exit point is applicable to:</p>
<p>Honours stream in the Bachelor of Software Engineering.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of the Honours thesis units, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>design a rigorous Bachelor Honours level research project and develop project proposal;</li>
<li>critically review research literature, research design and reported findings;</li>
<li>evaluate and select research methods and techniques of data collection and analysis appropriate to particular research designs, projects and disciplines;</li>
<li>conduct ethical research;</li>
<li>communicate research findings in written and oral form in research and industry settings.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of the requirements for the thesis the following components of assessment will be completed:</p>
<p>Research Proposal: 5%; Literature Review: 10%; Interim Presentation: hurdle; Final Presentation: 5%; Thesis (normally 10,000 - 20,000 words): 80%</p>
<p>These assessment tasks will be completed over the course of several units in the Honours program but the overall grade for the thesis will only be finalised on completion of either <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4444.html">FIT4444</a></span> (24 pts) or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4448.html">FIT4448</a></span> (18 pts).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week. Students will be expected to hold regular meetings with supervisor(s) over the course of the semester.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">GRS4104</span> - Reproductive health and fertility regulations<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-GRS4104">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-obstetrics-and-gynaecology.html">Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Temple-Smith">Associate Professor Peter Temple-Smith</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kiri Beilby">Dr Kiri Beilby</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=GRS4104&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-GRS4104">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-monash-medical-centre.html">Monash Medical Centre</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 0101, M5010</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit builds on earlier course work allowing the basic mechanisms of reproductive biology to be applied to key problems in reproductive health and fertility regulation. Sexual and reproductive disorders will be discussed in the context of public health and regulation.</p>
<p>Key elements of sexually transmitted diseases will be described to provide students with pathological and epidemiological perspectives.</p>
<p>Regulating the size of a population and the rate of population growth will be considered, with the current trends in population growth and the policies introduced in countries to regulate this growth explored.</p>
<p>The methods that men and women can apply to regulate their own fertility will be compared.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain in detail the disorders of sexual development and the normal processes involved in puberty and menopause</li>
<li>Identify key elements in the transfer of sexually transmitted disease</li>
<li>Recognise the mechanisms involved in reproductive cancers, menstrual disorders, erectile dysfunction and infertility</li>
<li>Appraise current approaches to the management of reproductive disorders</li>
<li>Identify and discuss the trends and policies for fertility regulation within populations</li>
<li>Critically evaluate the methods available to women and men to regulate their own fertility</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Examination (2 hours) (40%)</li>
<li>PeerWise (5%)</li>
<li>Creative thinking team assignment (20 minutes presentation) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Contraception case study in iSAP (1,500 words) (15%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will be held over six weeks in the second semester. Students are required to attend all lectures and tutorials. Student are also required to present an oral presentation.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/reproductive-sciences">Reproductive sciences</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="mailto:enquiries@med.monash.edu.au">enquiries@med.monash.edu.au</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_law"><span class="unitcode">LAW4130</span> - Law and social theory<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-LAW4130">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_law">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-law.html">Law</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Patrick Emerton">Assoc Prof Patrick Emerton</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-LAW4130">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB (Hons) course in 2015 or later:</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1111.html">LAW1111</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1114.html">LAW1114</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1112.html">LAW1112</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1113.html">LAW1113</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2101.html">LAW2101</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2102.html">LAW2102</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2112.html">LAW2112</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2111.html">LAW2111</a></span></p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB course prior to 2015:  LAW1100 OR LAW1101 and LAW1102 or LAW1104 or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2868.html">ATS2868</a></span>/3868, ATS2869/3869 or ATS2905/3905</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit examines:</p>
<ul>
<li>the notion of "social theory" and its relevance to an understanding of the law, history, industrial society and "modernity";</li>
<li>law, and the rule of law, as a social phenomenon;</li>
<li>law and social solidarity (Durkheim);</li>
<li>law as a system of social rules (Hart, Dworkin, Critical Legal Studies);</li>
<li>Marxist analysis of law;</li>
<li>criticisms of the Marxist analysis (Thompson, Williams, Krygier, Cohen, Rawls);</li>
<li>post-Marxist critical approaches to law (Habermas, Foucault); and</li>
<li>law and modernity (Weber).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this Unit, students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>be aware of, and be able to demonstrate their grasp of, the significance of social theory to the understanding of law as a social phenomenon;</li>
<li>be aware of the nature of social theoretic scholarship, and of the theoretical and methodological underpinnings that distinguish research and scholarship in the social sciences and humanities from research in law;</li>
<li>be able to produce written work that is adequate relative to the theoretical and methodological underpinnings mentioned in (2);</li>
<li>have closely read a number of primary texts in the social theoretic tradition having implications for the study of legal topics (both classical and contemporary texts, demonstrating a range of social theoretic approaches);</li>
<li>be able to communicate, in written form, the outcomes of the reading described in (4), and thereby display familiarity with, articulate the content of and undertake sustained critical analysis of those texts, synthesise multiple texts, and integrate their own social theoretic insights; and</li>
<li>learn and work autonomously and use feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Essay (3000 words): 60%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours writing time plus 10 minutes reading/ settling time): 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5135</span> - Video journalism<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5135">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-journalism.html">Journalism</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nick Parkin">Mr Nick Parkin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nick Parkin">Mr Nick Parkin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=APG5135&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5135">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit provides a detailed exploration of the production practices, resources, technologies and genres of Video Journalism, including broadcast and online modes. It develops the key performance practices of voice presentation and interviews, image and sound recording, editing and post-production. It critically considers the implications for journalists of different modes of audience engagement and editorial positioning, and covers news, current affairs, live reporting, online video journalism and feature/documentary video genres.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>demonstrate an ability to identify and research a story, conduct interviews and gather appropriate research and actuality material in the audiovisual media;</li>
<li>demonstrate an ability to report in a clear, concise, accurate and engaging way using a variety of audiovisual elements and narrative conventions in a video environment;</li>
<li>identify, observe key ethical and legal obligations associated with video journalism, and reflect critically on their own and others' performance in this regard;</li>
<li>work independently and collaboratively in learning and production processes to produce video journalism;</li>
<li>demonstrate an ability to set and meet deadlines, and report under pressure;</li>
<li>demonstrate an awareness of local, national and international people and events relevant to current issues and media issues along with a critical awareness of the capacities, limitations and socio-professional implications of journalistic practices in audiovisual media.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/communications-and-media-studies">Communications and media studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/journalism">Journalism</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MPH5286</span> - Applying and practicing the principles of patient safety and quality improvement<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MPH5286">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-epidemiology-and-preventive-medicine.html">Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Joseph Ibrahim">Professor Joseph Ibrahim</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Joseph Ibrahim">Professor Joseph Ibrahim</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MPH5286">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Unit <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MPH5267.html">MPH5267</a></span> must be completed prior to undertaking MPH5286.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in a Postgraduate course.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides students with the skills and knowledge to apply tools, techniques, programs or strategies to improve the quality of care and patient safety.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to have:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>An in-depth knowledge and ability to compare the key approaches to measuring, monitoring and managing health care for improving quality of care and patient safety;</li>
<li>An in-depth knowledge of the tools, techniques, programs and strategies currently used for improving quality of care and patient safety;</li>
<li>Demonstrate the skills to objectively critique the strengths and limitations of the different tool, technique, programs or strategy for improving quality of care and patient safety;</li>
<li>Demonstrate the ability to select an appropriate tool, technique, program or strategy for a:
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="i">
<li>particular dimension of quality (i.e. safety, efficacy, timelines, patient-centre-ed)</li>
<li>clinical setting</li>
<li>patient population</li>
<li>is logistically feasible</li>
</ol></li>
<li>Demonstrate the skills to modify, implement and evaluate a tool, technique, program or strategy for improving quality of care and patient safety in the workplace;</li>
<li>Understand and manage the factors that impact on the selection, acceptance and sustainability of initiative for improving quality of care and patient safety. These factors include clinician behaviour, organisational and health system structures.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Letter to the editor (500 words) (20%)</li>
<li>Reflective essay (2,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Online class participation (50%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week, broken down into (on average) 4 hours per week for reading core material, 4 hours per week completing exercises (manual, computer-based, or online), 2 hours per week for online communication via Moodle discussions, and 2 hours per week for assignment preparation.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>15 hours over 2 block days.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/public-health">Public health</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/epidemiology/pgrad">http://www.med.monash.edu.au/epidemiology/pgrad</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">CIV5881</span> - Ground water hydraulics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CIV5881">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-civil-engineering.html">Department of Civil Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeff Walker">Professor Jeff Walker</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Christian Urich">Dr Christian Urich</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Sina Alaghmand">Dr Sina Alaghmand</a>
        
        (Suzhou)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CIV5881&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CIV5881">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-suzhou.html">Suzhou</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit covers theoretical and practical knowledge of groundwater hydraulics, emphasizing analytical and numerical modelling skills.</p>
<p>The unit includes: aquifer properties, Darcy's law, well hydraulics, analytical and numerical modelling, model calibration, uncertainty analysis, contaminant fate and transport, variable density flow and ground water flow in unsaturated soils.</p>
<p>The knowledge learnt from this unit is directly applicable to research projects and practical industrial problems.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the fundamentals of subsurface flow and transport.</li>
<li>design hydraulic tests to obtain basic aquifer parameters.</li>
<li>derive analytical solutions for ground water flow and contaminant transport problems.</li>
<li>model ground water flow, solute transport and variable density flow numerically.</li>
<li>conduct model calibration, parameter estimation and sensitivity analysis.</li>
<li>work both independently and collaboratively on complex ground water problems.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>4 hours lectures/practice and 8 hours of private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Civil Engineering</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BFF3301</span> - Treasury and financial markets<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BFF3301">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-banking-and-finance.html">Department of Banking and Finance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wayne Huf">Mr Wayne Huf</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wayne Huf">Mr Wayne Huf</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Quota applies</p>
<p>Enrolment quota of 156 per semester
      
      
      </p><p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFF3301&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFF3301&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BFF3301">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFF2401.html">BFF2401</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will combine classroom teaching and direct experiential learning in financial markets covering topics that may include market participants, treasury operations, market structures, dealer markets, liquidity and price formation. This unit is taught in the simulated trading and research laboratory (STARLab). It is a specialist, practically oriented unit where attendance is compulsory as assessment is based on classroom activities. An understanding of financial prices, returns and volatility is required.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>formulate portfolio management decisions</li>
<li>compare and contrast differences between various market structures</li>
<li>acquire an in-depth understanding of economic concepts such as market efficiency, performance evaluation and market structure regulation</li>
<li>plan, verify and settle transactions completed in STARLab</li>
<li>develop, implement, analyse and manage strategies in financial markets</li>
<li>plan, organise and report on all activities involved in STARLab</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with treasury and financial markets.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">CHM3972</span> - Sustainable chemistry<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CHM3972">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-chemistry.html">School of Chemistry</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Katya Pas">Associate Professor Katya Pas</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Philip Wai Hong Chan">Professor Philip Wai Hong Chan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CHM3972&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CHM3972">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Six points of level one chemistry and six points of level two chemistry. Students without this should consult the level three co-ordinator.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The development of chemical tools that allow realisation of the concept of a sustainable future - meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs - is the basis for the course of sustainable chemistry.  This will be dealt with in three interconnected streams: Introduction to green chemistry, Sustainable technologies and Green energy technologies.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Discuss the historical and modern context of the birth and expansion of 'Green chemistry';</li>
<li>Explore the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community;</li>
<li>Investigate the principles of green chemistry and green metrics such as atom economy and e-factors to recognise green chemistry criteria in the practice of chemistry;</li>
<li>Identify reagents, reaction mechanisms and technologies that should be and realistically could be targeted for replacement by green alternatives;</li>
<li>Research examples of successful and recent sustainable chemistry technologies which enable environmental benefits through process changes and product substitution;</li>
<li>Debate the significance of energy in the global economy and associated energy related societal controversies;</li>
<li>Explore chemical processes involved in new technologies for the transport, storage and conversion of energy;</li>
<li>Construct strategies for improving energy efficiency and striving towards sustainability in energy consumption;</li>
<li>Practice technical skills for synthesising chemicals, interpreting chemical data, and collecting unique data using a range of sophisticated apparatus and technologies;</li>
<li>Develop methods and skills for communicating sustainable chemistry to a broad audience.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous/laboratory assessment: 35% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Group assessment: 15%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Hurdle requirement: To pass this unit a student must achieve a minimum score of 50% in the laboratory practical component and a minimum of 30% for the end-of-semester exam.</p>
<p>Supplementary assessment is not available for the lab practical component.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Two 1-hour workshops per week for 12 weeks and one 4-hour laboratory class every week for 10 weeks and one hour directed independent study</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/chemistry">Chemistry</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR5008</span> - Contemporary psychotherapies for nurses<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR5008">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Charanjit Singh">Mr Charanjit Singh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Charanjit Singh">Mr Charanjit Singh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5008&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR5008">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in a Postgraduate degree</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>In this unit students will study various contemporary psychotherapies and techniques used by nurses and other health professionals in interaction and counselling of clients with psychological and/or mental health disorders.</p>
<p>These therapies include: behavioural and cognitive therapies, Rational Emotive Therapy, Motivational Interviewing, Dialectal Behaviour Therapy, and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy.</p>
<p>This unit includes analysis of the theoretical underpinnings and major concepts of the therapies and other contemporary interventions for clinical application. Students will develop a greater self-awareness through the development of their own unique approaches to psychotherapeutic interactions utilising these contemporary approaches with their clients, within their own clinical and cultural environment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Use a variety of psychotherapeutic approaches and techniques that demonstrate skills and knowledge required for effective mental health nursing interaction.</li>
<li>Plan interventions and establish goals to meet the needs of clients within identified psychotherapeutic frameworks;</li>
<li>Critically analyse a variety of contemporary psychotherapies;</li>
<li>Develop a greater awareness of self and the ways in which personal attributes affect interaction with clients and others;</li>
<li>Practice relevant psychotherapeutic skills with a variety of clients displaying psychological disorders</li>
<li>Discuss a range of contemporary issues regarding psychotherapies and their techniques;</li>
<li>Critically appraise the evidence available regarding the efficacy of relevant psychotherapies with a variety of different client groups;</li>
<li>Optimise the opportunity as health professionals to enhance their clinical skills when working with consumers and carers;</li>
<li>Develop an understanding of cultural psychosocial aspects, which may influence the use of psychotherapies within the health professionals' roles.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Online discussion (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Written assignment (30%)</li>
<li>Case study (30%)</li>
<li>Four one day workshops (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing">Nursing</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/mental-health-nursing">Mental health nursing</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">OCC4092</span> - Transition to practice 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-OCC4092">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-occupational-therapy.html">Department of Occupational Therapy</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Lisa Knightbridge">Lisa Knightbridge</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Annette Peart">Annette Peart</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Luke Robinson">Luke Robinson</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=OCC4092&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-OCC4092">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OCC3062.html">OCC3062</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OCC3072.html">OCC3072</a></span> AND <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OCC4081.html">OCC4081</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OCC4071.html">OCC4071</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OCC4091.html">OCC4091</a></span>. Must be enrolled in Bachelor of Occupational Therapy.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will enable students to consider their own role within health and human service organisations, and apply and critique contemporary practice knowledge in areas such as leadership and management, team functioning and governance.</p>
<p>The Unit will conclude with a conference that includes presentations of research and project work from occupational therapy and physiotherapy students.</p>
<p>Students will complete a range of on-line tasks while completing their fieldwork placement as part of the unit <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OCC4082.html">OCC4082</a></span></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critique professional issues arising from contemporary practice as a result of organisational and team management, finance, and partnering with consumers;</li>
<li>Plan, participate in and present research/project findings at a professional conference;</li>
<li>Demonstrate effective presentation skills in written, visual and verbal modes;</li>
<li>Create an original scenario that highlights evidence-based occupational therapy intervention/s for a client or group in the context of a client's total service provision from an agency or organisation;</li>
<li>Demonstrate ability to reflect on own role within health and human service systems;</li>
<li>Critique own performance within an organisation or agency (e.g. self-management, own role and contribution in the team);</li>
<li>Identify areas for own continuing learning and professional development to support transition to practice.</li>
<li>Apply critical reflection skills, including providing effective feedback to peers</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Six video-conference forums (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Conference abstract (10%)</li>
<li>Scenario-based learning case study (3,000 words) (30%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Conference presentation (20 minutes) (20%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle: Attend minimum 80% of online activities, on-campus seminars and student conference</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Students are on fieldwork for 9 weeks with online tasks threaded through from week 1.</p>
<p>After the mid semester break, they are back on campus from week 10, with the 4th year interprofessional conference in week 12.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/occupational-therapy">Occupational therapy</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR5111</span> - Contemporary nursing practice 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR5111">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Scott">Mr Chris Scott</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Scott">Mr Chris Scott</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5111&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR5111&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR5111">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 3966, M6016</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is the first of four practice units in the graduate entry Master of Nursing Practice. The unit provides students with foundation knowledge and skills for nursing practice with an emphasis on physical health assessment. Knowledge and nursing practice skills are introduced around case scenarios.</p>
<p>Each case will use an individualised client centred approach. Content to be covered within each scenario will include physiology, introductory pharmacology, application of the legal and ethical dimensions of care and nursing skills development.</p>
<p>Clinical practice experience is an integral component of this unit and concentrates on the attainment of fundamental client care.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Apply anatomical and physiological principles to the outcomes of the patient assessment and care planning process.</li>
<li>Integrate scientific theory and clinical problem solving, communication and decision making skills to systematically assess a patient in the acute care clinical setting.</li>
<li>Plan and evaluate patient assessment data using clinical problem solving and decision making processes to justify care interventions across the lifespan of patients in acute care settings.</li>
<li>Plan, implement and evaluate nursing care using a person-centred approach cognisant of each individual's autonomy, self-esteem and dignity.</li>
<li>Apply the principles of pharmacology to therapeutic drug administration and monitoring to ensure the safe care of patients in a clinical setting.</li>
<li>Describe the legal and professional nursing requirements associated with quality use of medications including safe oral drug administration, storage and handling.</li>
<li>Perform basic nursing care skills to maintain and ensure patient safety using an evidence-based and professional approach in the clinical environment.</li>
<li>Identify the core principles of palliative care and the resources available for people with life limiting illness.</li>
<li>Practise in accordance with NMBA Registered Nurse standards for practice and other professional standards at a beginning level.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Clinical placement: 120 hours.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Active learning engagement (30%)</li>
<li>Case study (3000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Clinical performance (160 hours) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Clinical laboratory sessions - compulsory 100% attendance</li>
<li>Must complete clinical placement (120 hours)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Blended learning activities, including online and classroom sessions 6 hours/week; laboratories 2 hours/week; self-directed activities 4 hours/week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing">Nursing</a></p>
<p>Nursing and midwifery</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">SWM5008</span> - Planning for supervised professional practice placement 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">0 points, SCA Band 1, 0.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-SWM5008">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-social-work.html">Department of Social Work</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Samone McCurdy">Dr Samone McCurdy</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maura Bevilacqua">Maura Bevilacqua</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=SWM5008&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-SWM5008">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWM5103.html">SWM5103</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWM5102.html">SWM5102</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Master of Social Work (Qualifying) - 3969, M6012</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is structured to assist students in Planning and preparing for Supervised Professional Practice 2 (final Placement).</p>
<p>The unit consists of 6 preplacement tutorial/briefings.</p>
<p>Students complete Faculty and Departmental compliance requirements in this unit in order to proceed to a supervised professional practice placement.</p>
<p>The unit is a prerequisite for <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWM5108.html">SWM5108</a></span></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successfully completing this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse and synthesise skills and knowledge which demonstrate judgement and defined responsibility in relation to Faculty and department compliance and readiness for placement</li>
<li>Analyse, reflect and build on learning achieved in supervised professional practice 1 through participation in tutorials/briefings</li>
<li>Interpret and transmit knowledge of roles and responsibilities of those involved in supervised professional practice placement - the university, the student, and the host organisation by participating in tutorial/briefing activities</li>
<li>Integrate theory for social work practice by refining, expanding, and consolidating learning achieved during first placement in preparation for final placement, and through participation in tutorial/briefing activities</li>
<li>Interpret, analyse and synthesise the importance of supervision when undertaking supervised professional practice placement through participation in tutorial/briefing activities</li>
<li>Apply knowledge and skills which demonstrate autonomy, judgement, adaptability and responsibility in preparing effectively for supervised professional practice placement, by completing preparation for placement mandatory requirements such as Faculty and Departmental compliance documentation, and by participating in tutorials/briefings.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Preplacement tutorial/briefing 1 (hurdle)</li>
<li>Preplacement tutorial/briefing 2 (hurdle)</li>
<li>Preplacement tutorial/briefing 3 (hurdle)</li>
<li>Preplacement tutorial/briefing 4 (hurdle)</li>
<li>Preplacement tutorial/briefing 5 (hurdle)</li>
<li>Preplacement tutorial/briefing 6 (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Each hurdle builds on the previous hurdle</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will participate in 6 preplacement tutorial/briefings, comprising a mix of in class and online activities (up to 14 hours)</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>Students will participate in 6 preplacement tutorial/briefings, comprising  online activities (up to 14 hours)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/social-work">Social work</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_law"><span class="unitcode">LAW4164</span> - International refugee law and practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-LAW4164">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_law">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>

<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=LAW4164&amp;tpCode=T2-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 2</a>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-LAW4164">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-prato.html">Prato</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 2 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB (Hons) course in 2015 or later:</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1111.html">LAW1111</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1114.html">LAW1114</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1112.html">LAW1112</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW1113.html">LAW1113</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2101.html">LAW2101</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2102.html">LAW2102</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2112.html">LAW2112</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW2111.html">LAW2111</a></span></p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB course prior to 2015: LAW1100 OR LAW1101 and LAW1102 or LAW1104</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>For students who commenced their LLB (Hons) course in 2015 or later:  <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW3111.html">LAW3111</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/LAW3112.html">LAW3112</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This course will explore the international protection regime for refugees including state obligations under international refugee law, human rights and the law of the sea. It will compare and contrast key concepts and practices of refugee protection, amongst receiving states. It will then address issues raised by regional responses such as deterrence measures and the externalization of border control policies. This course will examine the sources of international refugee law and the evolution of the international regime for refugee protection. It will discuss comparative implementation of the refugee definition in Europe and other jurisdictions; modification of the Refugees Convention in domestic legislation; restrictive concepts such as 'internal protection' and 'safe third country' and the development of 'complementary protection' for asylum-seekers. It will then address issues raised by regional responses and creation of 'burden sharing' arrangements between states; procedures for determination of refugee status and proposals to reformulate the refugee protection regime.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of this unit, students should:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Articulate the background and nature of international refugee law.</li>
<li>Investigate and apply the international instruments applicable to asylum seekers, including the Refugees Convention.</li>
<li>Critically evaluate comparative state and regional practices towards refugee applicants.</li>
<li>Undertake legal research and reasoning to explain legal and policy issues so as to formulate reasoned and appropriate responses to legal problems in international refugee law.</li>
<li>Develop skills of oral presentation and argumentation in an interactive class context; and</li>
<li>Strategically apply feedback to improve capabilities and performance of tasks.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Attendance requirement: students who fail to attend at least 80% of the classes in this unit (ie who miss 3 or more classes) will receive a result of 0 N for the unit. Students who are unable to meet this requirement due to severe illness or other exceptional circumstances must make an application for in-semester special consideration with supporting documentation.</p>
<p>Research Assignment (3,000 words): 60%</p>
<p>Take Home Examination (1,500 words): 30%</p>
<p>Class participation: 10%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS1112</span> - Indonesian 2: Journeys and cultural encounters<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS1112">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-indonesian-studies.html">Indonesian Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yacinta Kurniasih">Ms Yacinta Kurniasih</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yacinta Kurniasih">Ms Yacinta Kurniasih</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS1112&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS1112">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1111.html">ATS1111</a></span> or equivalent</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>Students are not permitted to take classes that are below their language proficiency level.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>If this is your language entry point, this unit requires a <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">language entry level test</a><span class="hbk-print-url">language entry level test (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit aims to consolidate and extend cultural knowledge and communication skills commenced in <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1111.html">ATS1111</a></span>. The primary theme of the unit is focused on journeys or travel as an influence on cultural interaction and personal awareness. The cultural lectures explore journeys in road films and literature through translated text. The tutorials provide opportunities for language practice and presentations related to students own journeys. Students taking this unit are required to have completed <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1111.html">ATS1111</a></span> or have acquired a basic knowledge of Indonesian language and culture through formal study or in-country experience.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>apply an extended knowledge of the Indonesian language to present experiences related to journeys or travel;</li>
<li>query and discuss common contrasting and shared cultural practices in daily life;</li>
<li>discuss, present, and apply frequently used Indonesian grammatical forms related to word formation and sentence structure;</li>
<li>apply basic research skills to retrieve, synthesise and communicate information related to significant historical or contemporary journeys made through the Indonesian/Malay Archipelago in English.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 75% + Exam: 25%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/indonesian-studies">Indonesian studies</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMA1902</span> - Human structure and function 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMA1902">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Natalie Bennett">Dr Natalie Bennett</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Elise Randle-Barrett">Dr Elise Randle-Barrett</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMA1902&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMA1902">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1901.html">BMA1901</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in Bachelor of Occupational Therapy (Honours), Bachelor of Education or Bachelor of Health Sciences.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1012.html">BMA1012</a></span>, BMA1912, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS2011.html">BMS2011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS2031.html">BMS2031</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PHY2011.html">PHY2011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1114.html">NUR1114</a></span> PHY2021, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PHY2032.html">PHY2032</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PHY2042.html">PHY2042</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is the second in a sequence of two health science units that provides foundation knowledge of human anatomy and physiology relevant for allied health professions and further develops skills in the critical evaluation of evidence.</p>
<p>The major themes of study in this unit are: body support and movement, cardiovascular anatomy and physiology, the respiratory system, the urinary system and the control of body fluids; the digestive system and the processing of nutrients in the body; the lymphoid/immune system; microbes and infection; and an introduction to pharmacological principles.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Relate the structure of the major bones, joints and muscles to the functions of support and movement;</li>
<li>Summarise the structures of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems and explain how their integrated functions facilitate transport and maintain homeostasis;</li>
<li>Locate the organs of the digestive system and describe the processes of digestion, absorption and metabolism;</li>
<li>Consider how urine is formed and the role of the kidneys in maintaining fluid composition and balance;</li>
<li>Outline the body's innate and adaptive defences and how they determine the nature of interactions with microbes;</li>
<li>Outline basic pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principals as a foundation for understanding pharmacology;</li>
<li>Analyse and interpret data using an evidence based  approach to understand patient symptoms.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Online tests (10 x 10 minutes each) (MCQ) (10%)</li>
<li>Mid-semester exam (MCQ) (35 minutes) (20%)</li>
<li>Laboratory test (1 hour) (25%)</li>
<li>Examination (2 hours) (MCQ/ SAQ) (45%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle Requirement: Students must pass the Examination to pass the unit.</p>
<p>You are also required to attend all scheduled unit tutorials and practical sessions unless documentary evidence (such as a medical certificate, relevant death notice, etc.) is provided.</p>
<p>Minimum attendance requirement of 80% to pass the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours of lectures and 1.5 hour tutorial per week and 2 hours practical per fortnight. An additional 6 hours of self-directed study is recommended.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
